messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Faster algorithms on linear delta-matroids

Paper Abstract: Abstract We show new algorithms and constructions over linear delta-matroids. We observe an alternative representation for linear delta-matroids, as a contraction representation over a skew-symmetric matrix. This is equivalent to the more standard ‚Äútwist representation‚Äù up to O‚Äã(nœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùúîO(n^{\omega})-time transformations (where nùëõn is the dimension of the delta-matroid and œâ<2.372ùúî2.372\omega<2.372 the matrix multiplication exponent), but is much more convenient for algorithmic tasks. For instance, the problem of finding a max-weight feasible set now reduces directly to the problem of finding a max-weight basis in a linear matroid. Supported by this representation, we provide new algorithms and constructions over linear delta-matroids. We show that the union and delta-sum of linear delta-matroids define linear delta-matroids, and a representation for the resulting delta-matroid can be constructed in randomized time O‚Äã(nœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùúîO(n^{\omega}) (or more precisely, in O‚Äã(nœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùúîO(n^{\omega}) field operations, over a field of at least Œ©‚Äã(n‚ãÖ(1/Œµ))Œ©‚ãÖùëõ1ùúÄ\Omega(n\cdot(1/\varepsilon)) elements, where Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 is an error parameter). Previously, it was only known that these operations define delta-matroids. We also note that every projected linear delta-matroid can be represented as an elementary projection. This implies that several optimization problems over (projected) linear delta-matroids, including the coverage, delta-coverage, and parity problems, reduce (in their decision versions) to a single O‚Äã(nœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùúîO(n^{\omega})-time matrix rank computation. Using the methods of Harvey, previously used by Cheung, Lao and Leung for linear matroid parity, we furthermore show how to solve the search versions in the same time. This improves on the O‚Äã(n4)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ4O(n^{4})-time augmenting path algorithm of Geelen, Iwata and Murota. Finally, we consider the maximum-cardinality delta-matroid intersection problem (or equivalently, the maximum-cardinality delta-matroid matching problem). Using Storjohann‚Äôs algorithms for symbolic determinants, we show that such a solution can be found in O‚Äã(nœâ+1)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõùúî1O(n^{\omega+1}) time. This is the first polynomial-time algorithm for the problem, solving an open question of Kakimura and Takamatsu.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Breaking O(nr) for matroid intersection",
        "Fast algorithms via dynamic-oracle matroids",
        "Greedy algorithm and symmetric matroids",
        "Matchings and ŒîŒî\\Delta-matroids",
        "Coverings and delta-coverings",
        "Delta-matroids, jump systems, and bisubmodular polyhedra",
        "The delta-sum of matching delta-matroids",
        "Faster matroid intersection",
        "Algebraic algorithms for linear matroid parity problems",
        "An algorithm for packing non-zero A-paths in group-labelled graphs",
        "Packing non-zero A-paths in group-labelled graphs",
        "Matroids, delta-matroids and embedded graphs",
        "On the interplay between embedded graphs and delta-matroids",
        "General factors of graphs",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Algorithmic applications of Baur-Strassen‚Äôs theorem: Shortest cycles, diameter, and matchings",
        "Optimal general matchings",
        "On planar Boolean CSP",
        "Determinantal sieving",
        "Fanout limitations on constraint systems",
        "Efficient computation of representative families with applications in parameterized and exact algorithms",
        "Kernelization: Theory of Parameterized Preprocessing",
        "Algorithms for weighted matching generalizations I: Bipartite graphs, b-matching, and unweighted f-factors",
        "Circle graph obstructions under pivoting",
        "A generalization of Tutte‚Äôs characterization of totally unimodular matrices",
        "The excluded minors for GF(4)-representable matroids",
        "The linear delta-matroid parity problem",
        "Obstructions for bounded branch-depth in matroids",
        "Algebraic algorithms for matching and matroid problems",
        "Minor summation formula of Pfaffians",
        "A weighted linear matroid parity algorithm",
        "Matching problems with delta-matroid constraints",
        "Even delta-matroids and the complexity of planar Bpolean CSPs",
        "Optimal general factor problem and jump system intersection",
        "Compression via matroids: A randomized polynomial kernel for odd cycle transversal",
        "Representative sets and irrelevant vertices: New tools for kernelization",
        "Matroid matching and some applications",
        "Pfaffian pairs and parities: Counting on linear matroid intersection and parity problems",
        "Delta-matroids for graph theorists",
        "Matrices and matroids for systems analysis, volume 20",
        "Excluding a bipartite circle graph from line graphs",
        "Rank-width: Algorithmic and structural results",
        "Matroid Theory",
        "Packing non-returning Aùê¥A-paths",
        "Packing non-returning Aùê¥A-paths algorithmically",
        "Maximum matchings in general graphs through randomization",
        "Combinatorial Optimization: Polyhedra and Efficiency",
        "Fast probabilistic algorithms for verification of polynomial identities",
        "High-order lifting and integrality certification",
        "Packing non-zero A-paths via matroid matching",
        "A combinatorial equivalence of matrices",
        "Modern computer algebra",
        "Representative set statements for delta-matroids and the Mader delta-matroid",
        "Packing A-paths in group-labelled graphs via linear matroid parity",
        "Shortest disjoint S-paths via weighted linear matroid parity",
        "Probabilistic algorithms for sparse polynomials"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Faster algorithms on linear delta-matroids, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
